text:
One case that has recently
enabled me to think differently

about my research and projects
that I've been working on

is the Rosalind Fox
at John Deere case.

It's a case that dives deep
into issues of authenticity,

and particularly
who has the license
to be authentic at work.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Teaching the Rob Parson's case
has highlighted the distinction

between being able
to do one's work well

and being able to coach someone
else in doing that work.

And a lot of the
research I'm doing

is focused on how we
equip people to actually

be good at developing
other individuals.

The case featuring
Kwame Owusu-Kesse

has got me thinking,
once again, what

are we teaching our
students, and how can I

teach our students about
forming relationships.

Every time I teach a case,
particularly my own cases,

our students always teach me
something about my research

that I hadn't
previously considered.

For me, it's Erik
Peterson, day one and two.

Learning about all the
things that have gone wrong

and could have
gone better really

make me reflect about
how I lead and how
I conduct my own research.

It is the case about
Jean Rogers when

she created the Sustainability
Accounting Standards

Board, that's an organization
that has developed metrics

to measure the social and
environmental performance
of organizations.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
